awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Using electromyography (EMG) signals for advanced human-machine interface of amputees and bionic upper limb prosthetics
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to develop a novel human-machine interface and machine learning system for upper limb prosthetic control. More broadly, the project aims to develop comprehensive, non-invasive, neural interfaces for human-robotics control. This resesarch and development deepens scientific understanding of how to decipher motor control signals from peripheral nerves and their innervated muscles.  The team also pursues technological and form factor understanding of highly-usable human-attached robotics. 


This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to deliver solutions to the problem of today’s underdeveloped prosthetics for those who suffer from upper extremity limb loss. The primary research objective is to discover a set of hardware, firmware, and software that enable real-time human-robotic controls. This research ranges from machine learning training platforms, to electromyography and sonomyography input systems, to industrial design that reduces the stigma associated with prostheses. Technical results of this project include the foundation for deep learning training approaches, mature signal transfer methodology, and arm band design that ensures real-time signal processing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Our company is creating an active system prosthetic arm addressing major customer pain points in current prosthetic arms. The main goal of this project is to create breakthroughs in robotics, neural interfacing, control software, and user-friendly attachments.

 

The primary pain points are:

  • No individual finger control, e.g., limited to 10 hand grips

  • Limited range of motion, e.g., user can?t position arm above shoulder

  • Limited gross motor dexterity, e.g., only partial wrist movement

  • No simultaneous joint control

  • No proportional joint control

  • No sense of touch, e.g., motor control driven purely by vision

  • Non-intuitive control, eg., requires significant cognitive overhead

  • Heavy and often painful to wear and use

 

The ideal outcome is to provide upper limb amputees with a prosthetic arm that achieves orders of magnitude more functionality and usability than the most advanced prosthetic currently on the market.

 

In developing this offering for users, our main areas of research were:

  • Advanced robotics

  • Technologies to confer tactile feedback

  • Surface EMG neural interfacing

  • Limited to no increase in cognitive load with new advancements

  • How to increase comfort & wearability

  • ?Smart? AI-based software that can ?fill the gap? between user input and robotic output

 

Findings:

  • Robotics have progressed since the advent of modern myoelectric prosthetics in the 2000s, and thus is a good candidate for R&D to improve prosthetic functionality.

  • sEMG is a sufficient control schema for all levels of arm amputation. It establishes full gross motor control (elbow, wrist, hand grips) and sometimes fine motor control (fingers).

  • sEMG can provide significant fine motor control but is highly individualized, thus requiring personalized training.

  • Technologies like AI, computer vision, and machine learning would likely improve controllability and decrease cognitive load even more.

  • More user-friendly attachments ? attaching the prosthetic to the body ? than today?s products may significantly improve comfort, weight balance, and quality of life.

 

Results:

  • Promising early results that sEMG is sufficient for gross and fine motor control.

  • Promising leads on better robotics for better overall functionality.

  • Promising early results that user-friendly attachments have a positive effect in significantly improving comfort & weight balance, and may prevent negative effects of users immediately discarding their prosthetics and never using them again.

 

We?re confident these early results and conversations will lead to a step function-improved prosthetic system. A Phase 2 project is warranted to further this system, run user tests, and provide measurements of these improvements.


 


Last Modified: 08/29/2022
Modified by: Tyler Hayes
